Description: Upper body sherd (consisting of two joining fragments) of Corinthian black-figured pottery column-krater; exterior: below junction of neck and shoulder, black-figure decoration: cock standing (head, neck and most of body remaining) to left; incised splinter rosettes as filling ornament.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Bibliographic references: Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 121, pl. XXXVII, no. 341.1)
Payne 1931 / Necrocorinthia. A study of corinthian art in the archaic period (p. 340)
Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 229, no. 148) (Labelled 4665/4666)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.194) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4664 / 4665 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
